Author full names: Price, Mark D. (7401948425); Somaroo, Shyamal S. (6603356725); Dunlop, Amy E. (12545040900); Havel, Timothy F. (7003282278); Cory, David G. (7007071262)
Title: Generalized methods for the development of quantum logic gates for an NMR quantum information processor
Source title: Physical Review A - Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics
Affiliations: Harvard–MIT Division of Health Sciences and Technology, Cambridge, MA, 02139, United States; BCMP, Harvard Medical School, Boston, MA, 02115, United States; Department of Nuclear Engineering, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA, 02139, United States
Authors with affiliations: Price M.D., Harvard–MIT Division of Health Sciences and Technology, Cambridge, MA, 02139, United States; Somaroo S.S., BCMP, Harvard Medical School, Boston, MA, 02115, United States; Dunlop A.E., Department of Nuclear Engineering, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA, 02139, United States; Havel T.F., BCMP, Harvard Medical School, Boston, MA, 02115, United States; Cory D.G., Department of Nuclear Engineering, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA, 02139, United States
Abstract: Logic gates such as the controlled-NOT (c-NOT) and Toffoli gates play a key role in quantum information processing (QIP) and quantum computing. A natural extension of such gates would necessarily operate on one quantum bit (qubit) conditional on the state of the remaining qubits in the system. We show that such selective gates, termed [Formula Presented] gates, or [Formula Presented] gates, are convenient in nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) implementations of QIP and are straightforward to implement. NMR pulse sequences for these gates can be built using classical methods as well as insights from geometric algebra. These methods yield equivalent NMR pulse sequences for the generation of [Formula Presented] gates for any number of control spins. In this work, a catalog of [Formula Presented] gates for systems of as many as 16 spins is provided along with an experimental implementation of a [Formula Presented] gate on a four spin system, [Formula Presented] alanine. © 1999 The American Physical Society.

Title: Quantum computing with electrons floating on liquid helium
Source title: Science
Affiliations: Bell Laboratories, Lucent Technologies, Murray Hill, NJ 07974, United States; Michigan State University, Department of Physics and Astronomy, East Lansing, MI 48824, United States
Authors with affiliations: Platzman P.M., Bell Laboratories, Lucent Technologies, Murray Hill, NJ 07974, United States; Dykman M.I., Michigan State University, Department of Physics and Astronomy, East Lansing, MI 48824, United States
Abstract: A quasi-two-dimensional set of electrons (1 < N < 109) in vacuum, trapped in one-dimensional hydrogenic levels above a micrometer-thick film of liquid helium, is proposed as an easily manipulated strongly interacting set of quantum bits. Individual electrons are laterally confined by micrometer- sized metal pads below the helium. Information is stored in the lowest hydrogenic levels. With electric fields, at temperatures of 10-2 kelvin, changes in the wave function can be made in nanoseconds. Wave function coherence times are 0.1 millisecond. The wave function is read out with an inverted dc voltage, which releases excited electrons from the surface.

Title: Quantum computing with trapped ions
Source title: IQEC, International Quantum Electronics Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Natl Inst of Standards and, Technology, Boulder, CO, United States
Authors with affiliations: Monroe C., Natl Inst of Standards and, Technology, Boulder, CO, United States; Itano W.M., Natl Inst of Standards and, Technology, Boulder, CO, United States; Kielpinski D., Natl Inst of Standards and, Technology, Boulder, CO, United States; King B.E., Natl Inst of Standards and, Technology, Boulder, CO, United States; Myatt C.J., Natl Inst of Standards and, Technology, Boulder, CO, United States; Sackett C.A., Natl Inst of Standards and, Technology, Boulder, CO, United States; Turchette Q.A., Natl Inst of Standards and, Technology, Boulder, CO, United States; Wineland D.J., Natl Inst of Standards and, Technology, Boulder, CO, United States
Abstract: The most promising physical system for the realization of a quantum computer is a collection of trapped atomic ions. Internal electronic states of the ions is shown to act as quantum bits, and with the use of quantum logic operations, they are coupled through their collective motion in the trap.

Authors: Bass R.B.; Zhang J.Z.; Lichtenberger A.W.
Author full names: Bass, Robert B. (57191852951); Zhang, Jian Z. (7601353693); Lichtenberger, Aurthur W. (35583434700)
Title: Machine-aligned fabrication of submicron SIS tunnel junctions using a focused ion beam
Source title: IEEE Transactions on Applied Superconductivity
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Virginia, Charlottesville, VA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bass R.B., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Virginia, Charlottesville, VA, United States; Zhang J.Z., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Virginia, Charlottesville, VA, United States; Lichtenberger A.W., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Virginia, Charlottesville, VA, United States
Abstract: The objective of our research is to develop a machine-aligned technique for the definition and insulation of Nb/Al-AlOx/Nb superconductingimsulating-superconducting (SIS) tunnel junctions with areas as small as 0.2|am2. The fabrication of such ultrasmall area planar SIS junctions had previously only been achieved using electron beam lithography (JPL). Typical techniques for the fabrication of micron-scale SIS junctions involve a self-aligned resist lift-off process. The resist pattern is used to define both the junction counter-electrode and the insulation field that separates the wiring layer from the base electrode. The wiring layer contacts the junction counter-electrode through a via in the insulation field that is created during resist liftoff. In our process, the junction is defined and insulated in separate steps; a via through the insulation layer to the junction is aligned and defined using a gallium focused ion beam with nanometer spot-size. Such small area SIS junctions have potential applications in high frequency SIS mixer circuits. They may also be used in experiments to investigate quantum coherence in superconducting circuits and may even serve as the key elements in future superconducting quantum computers. © 1999 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Electrodes; Gallium; Integrated circuits; Ion bombardment; Niobium compounds; Superconducting materials; Focused ion beam; Machine aligned technique; Superconducting insulating superconducting tunnel junctions; Tunnel junctions

Title: Superconducting circuits for quantum computing
Source title: HP Laboratories Technical Report
Affiliations: Trusted E-Services Laboratory, HP Laboratories Bristol, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Spiller T.P., Trusted E-Services Laboratory, HP Laboratories Bristol, United Kingdom
Abstract: Superconducting circuits provide one of the numerous current candidate routes for the realization of quantum computing (QC) technology. In this paper I review the basic physics behind this candidature and outline some superconducting QC proposals currently on the table, demonstrating their common origins. More detailed discussion of the proposals follows, assessing how they measure up to the "DiVincenzo checklist" for QC realizations and the current status of experiments.

Authors: Fenner S.; Green F.; Homer S.; Pruim R.
Author full names: Fenner, Stephen (7003418623); Green, Frederic (57196759421); Homer, Steven (7004013557); Pruim, Randall (12144212000)
Title: Determining acceptance possibility for a quantum computation is hard for the polynomial hierarchy
Source title: Proceedings of the Royal Society A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences
Affiliations: Computer Science Department, University of South Carolina, Columbia, SC 29208, United States; Department of Mathematics and Computer Science, Clark University, Worcester, MA 01610, United States; Computer Science Department, Boston University, Boston, MA 02215, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fenner S., Computer Science Department, University of South Carolina, Columbia, SC 29208, United States; Green F., Department of Mathematics and Computer Science, Clark University, Worcester, MA 01610, United States; Homer S., Computer Science Department, Boston University, Boston, MA 02215, United States; Pruim R., Computer Science Department, University of South Carolina, Columbia, SC 29208, United States, Department of Mathematics and Computer Science, Clark University, Worcester, MA 01610, United States, Computer Science Department, Boston University, Boston, MA 02215, United States
Abstract: It is shown that determining whether a quantum computation has a non-zero probability of accepting is at least as hard as the polynomial-time hierarchy. This hardness result also applies to determining in general whether a given quantum basis state appears with non-zero amplitude in a superposition, or whether a given quantum bit has positive expectation value at the end of a quantum computation. This result is achieved by showing that the complexity class NQP (a quantum analogue of NP) of Adleman, Démarrais and Huang is equal to the counting class coC-P. © 1999 The Royal Society.
Author Keywords: Complexity theory; Polynomial-time hierarchy; Quantum computing; Quantum np
Funding Details: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering, CISE, (9400229)

Title: Josephson persistent-current qubit

S., Delft University of Technology, 2600 GA Delft, Post Office Box 5046, Netherlands; Lloyd S., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Massachusetts Inst. of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139, United States
Abstract: A qubit was designed that can be fabricated with conventional electron beam lithography and is suited for integration into a large quantum computer. The qubit consists of a micrometer-sized loop with three or four Josephson junctions; the two qubit states have persistent currents of opposite direction. Quantum superpositions of these states are obtained by pulsed microwave modulation of the enclosed magnetic flux by currents in control lines. A superconducting flux transporter allows for controlled transfer between qubits of the flux that is generated by the persistent currents, leading to entanglement of qubit information.

Title: Field computation in natural and artificial intelligence
Source title: Information sciences
Affiliations: Computer Science Department, University of Tennessee, Knoxville, TN 37916, United States
Authors with affiliations: MacLennan B.J., Computer Science Department, University of Tennessee, Knoxville, TN 37916, United States
Abstract: We review the concepts of field computation, a model of computation that processes information represented as spatially continuous arrangements of continuous data. We show that many processes in the brain are described usefully as field computation. Throughout we stress the connections between field computation and quantum mechanics, especially including the important role of information fields, which represent by virtue of their form rather than their magnitude. We also show that field computation permits simultaneous nonlinear computation in linear superposition.

Title: Quantum communication and quantum computing
Source title: IQEC, International Quantum Electronics Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Imperial Coll, London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Knight Peter L., Imperial Coll, London, United Kingdom
Abstract: Quantum mechanics offers the information scientist a new rich resource, which is being tapped for secure communication in the form of quantum cryptography, and for tremendous parallelism in quantum information processing and computing. Quantum cryptography has already advanced beyond the research laboratory to become a realizable technology with proven secret key distribution for encryption. Quantum computing is a major new development in physics, addressing problems too complex for normal computation in a reasonable time.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Cryptography; Information science; Information theory; Security of data; Quantum communication; Quantum computing; Quantum cryptography; Quantum entanglement; Quantum theory
Sponsors: APS; IEEE; OSA-Optical Society of America

Title: Microscopic analogs of the Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger experiment on an NMR quantum computer
Source title: Physical Review A - Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics
Affiliations: Department of Commerce, Kumamoto Gakuen University, Kumamoto, 862-8680, Japan; Computer Centre, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, 113-8658, Bunkyo-ku, Japan; Department of Chemistry, Kanagawa University, Hiratsuka, 259-1293, Japan; Osaka National Research Institute, Ikeda, 563-8577, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sakaguchi U., Department of Commerce, Kumamoto Gakuen University, Kumamoto, 862-8680, Japan; Ozawa H., Computer Centre, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, 113-8658, Bunkyo-ku, Japan; Amano C., Department of Chemistry, Kanagawa University, Hiratsuka, 259-1293, Japan; Fukumi T., Osaka National Research Institute, Ikeda, 563-8577, Japan
Abstract: A scheme is proposed to implement microscopic analogs of the Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger experiment, as described by Lloyd, on a nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) quantum computer. This scheme includes how to prepare the effective pure spin state |0000〉 (a state with all the spins pointing along the direction of the magnetic field) from a state at thermal equilibrium, how to transform it into states of the form, e.g., [Formula Presented] (which comprises the first three spins in an entangled state and the fourth register-spin), and how to measure the eigenvalue of the operator product like [Formula Presented] for such three-spin entangled states, where [Formula Presented] is the Pauli matrix for the [Formula Presented] spin, and store the result on the fourth spin. Also proposed is a general method to implement the controlled-not gate, an essential gate for any quantum algorithm, on n-qubit NMR quantum computers with [Formula Presented]. © 1999 The American Physical Society.

Authors: Long G.L.; Li Y.S.; Zhang W.L.; Niu L.
Title: Phase matching in quantum searching
Source title: Physics Letters, Section A: General, Atomic and Solid State Physics
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China
Authors with affiliations: Long G.L., Department of Physics, Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China; Li Y.S., Department of Physics, Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China; Zhang W.L., Department of Physics, Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China; Niu L., Department of Physics, Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China
Abstract: When arbitrary phase rotations are used instead of inversions in Grover's quantum algorithm, they must satisfy a matching condition. When phase matching is satisfied, the quantum search is an approximate rotation in 2-dimensional space. An approximate formula for the amplitude is derived. A simple explanation is also given. © 1999 Published by Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved.

Title: Calculating the thermal rate constant with exponential speedup on a quantum computer
Source title: Physical Review E - Statistical Physics, Plasmas, Fluids, and Related Interdisciplinary Topics
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, University of California at Berkeley, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lidar D.A., Department of Chemistry, University of California at Berkeley, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Wang H., Department of Chemistry, University of California at Berkeley, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Abstract: It is shown how to formulate the ubiquitous quantum chemistry problem of calculating the thermal rate constant on a quantum computer. The resulting exact algorithm scales exponentially faster with the dimensionality of the system than all known "classical" algorithms for this problem.

Authors: Makhlin Y.; Schön G.; Shnirman A.
Author full names: Makhlin, Yuriy (7003487723); Schön, Gerd (7006099229); Shnirman, Alexander (6603674816)
Title: Josephson-junction qubits with controlled couplings
Source title: Nature
Affiliations: Inst. F. Theor. Festkorperphysik, Universität Karlsruhe, D-76128 Karlsruhe, Germany; Landau Inst. for Theoretical Physics, 117940 Moscow, Kosygin Street 2, Russian Federation; Department of Physics, Univ. Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, Illinois 61801, United States
Authors with affiliations: Makhlin Y., Inst. F. Theor. Festkorperphysik, Universität Karlsruhe, D-76128 Karlsruhe, Germany, Landau Inst. for Theoretical Physics, 117940 Moscow, Kosygin Street 2, Russian Federation; Schön G., Inst. F. Theor. Festkorperphysik, Universität Karlsruhe, D-76128 Karlsruhe, Germany; Shnirman A., Department of Physics, Univ. Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, Illinois 61801, United States
Abstract: Quantum computers, if available, could perform certain tasks much more efficiently than classical computers by exploiting different physical principles. A quantum computer would be comprised of coupled, two-state quantum systems or qubits, whose coherent time evolution must be controlled in a computation. Experimentally, trapped ions, nuclear magnetic resonance in molecules, and quantum optical systems have been investigated for embodying quantum computation. But solid-state implementations would be more practical, particularly nanometre-scale electronic devices: these could be easily embedded in electronic circuitry and scaled up to provide the large numbers of qubits required for useful computations. Here we present a proposal for solid-state qubits that utilizes controllable, low-capacitance Josephson junctions. The design exploits coherent tunnelling of Cooper pairs in the superconducting state, while employing the control mechanisms of single-charge devices: single- and two-bit operations can be controlled by gate voltages. The advantages of using tunable Josephson couplings include the simplification of the operation and the reduction of errors associated with permanent couplings.; Quantum computers, if available, could-perform certain tasks much more efficiently than classical computers by exploiting different physical principles. A quantum computer would be comprised of coupled, two-state quantum systems or qubits, whose coherent time evolution must be controlled in a computation. Experimentally, trapped ions, nuclear magnetic resonance in molecules, and quantum optical systems have been investigated for embodying quantum computation. But solid-state implementations would be more practical, particularly nanometre-scale electronic devices: these could be easily embedded in electronic circuitry and scaled up to provide the large numbers of qubits required for useful computations. Here we present a proposal for solid-state qubits that utilizes controllable, low-capacitance Josephson junctions. The design exploits coherent tunnelling of Cooper pairs in the superconducting state, while employing the control mechanisms of single charge devices: single- and two-bit operations can be controlled by gate voltages. The advantages of using tunable Josephson couplings include the simplification of the operation and the reduction of errors associated with permanent couplings.

Title: Quantum information processing using quantum dot spins and cavity qed
Source title: Physical Review Letters
Affiliations: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of California, Santa Barbara, CA, 93106, United States; Department of Physics, University of California, Santa Barbara, CA, 93106, United States; Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of Basel, Basel, CH-4056, Klingelbergstrasse 82, Switzerland; IBM Research Division, T. Box 218, Yorktown Heights, United States; Loss D., Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of Basel, Basel, CH-4056, Klingelbergstrasse 82, Switzerland; Sherwin M., Department of Physics, University of California, Santa Barbara, CA, 93106, United States; Small A., Department of Physics, University of California, Santa Barbara, CA, 93106, United States
Abstract: The electronic spin degrees of freedom in semiconductors typically have decoherence times that are several orders of magnitude longer than other relevant time scales. A solid-state quantum computer based on localized electron spins as qubits is therefore of potential interest. Here, a scheme that realizes controlled interactions between two distant quantum dot spins is proposed. The effective long-range interaction is mediated by the vacuum field of a high finesse microcavity. By using conduction-band-hole Raman transitions induced by classical laser fields and the cavity-mode, parallel controlled-not operations, and arbitrary single qubit rotations can be realized. © 1999 The American Physical Society.

Authors: Ben-Jacob E.; Hermon Z.; Caspi S.
Title: DNA transistor and quantum bit element: Realization of nano-biomolecular logical devices
Source title: Physics Letters, Section A: General, Atomic and Solid State Physics
Affiliations: School of Physics and Astronomy, Tel Aviv University, 69978 Tel Aviv, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Ben-Jacob E., School of Physics and Astronomy, Tel Aviv University, 69978 Tel Aviv, Israel; Hermon Z., School of Physics and Astronomy, Tel Aviv University, 69978 Tel Aviv, Israel; Caspi S., School of Physics and Astronomy, Tel Aviv University, 69978 Tel Aviv, Israel
Abstract: Based on the theoretical prediction that chemical bonds can act as tunnel junctions in the Coulomb blockade regime, and on the technical ability to coat a DNA strand with metal, we suggest that DNA can be used to built nano-logical devices. We discuss two explicit examples: a single-electron tunneling transistor (SET) and a quantum bit element. These devices would be literally in the nano-meter scale and would be able to operate at room temperature. In addition they would be highly stable and have a self ably property. © 1999 Published by Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved.

Title: Higher-order methods for simulations on quantum computers
Source title: Physical Review A - Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics
Affiliations: NASA/Fermilab Astrophysics Group, Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory, Batavia, IL, 60510-0500, Box 500, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sornborger A.T., NASA/Fermilab Astrophysics Group, Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory, Batavia, IL, 60510-0500, Box 500, United States; Stewart E.D., NASA/Fermilab Astrophysics Group, Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory, Batavia, IL, 60510-0500, Box 500, United States
Abstract: To implement many-qubit gates for use in quantum simulations on quantum computers efficiently, we develop and present methods reexpressing [Formula Presented] as a product of factors [Formula Presented] [Formula Presented], which is accurate to third or fourth order in [Formula Presented]. The methods we derive are an extended form of the symplectic method, and can also be used for an integration of classical Hamiltonians on classical computers. We derive both integral and irrational methods, and find the most efficient methods in both cases. © 1999 The American Physical Society.

Title: Polynomial-time algorithms for prime factorization and discrete logarithms on a quantum computer
Source title: SIAM Review
Affiliations: AT and T Labs.-Research, Florham Park, NJ 07932, 180 Park Avenue, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shor P.W., AT and T Labs.-Research, Florham Park, NJ 07932, 180 Park Avenue, United States
Abstract: A digital computer is generally believed to be an efficient universal computing device; that is, it is believed to be able to simulate any physical computing device with an increase in computation time by at most a polynomial factor. This may not be true when quantum mechanics is taken into consideration. This paper considers factoring integers and finding discrete logarithms, two problems that are generally thought to be hard on classical computers and that have been used as the basis of several proposed cryptosystems. Efficient randomized algorithms are given for these two problems on a hypothetical quantum computer. These algorithms take a number of steps polynomial in the input size, for example, the number of digits of the integer to be factored.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Digital computers; Fourier transforms; Number theory; Polynomials; Quantum theory; Random processes; Church thesis; Discrete logarithms; Polynomial time algorithms; Prime factorization; Quantum computers; Spin systems; Algorithms

Author full names: Barnes, Jeff P. (55415849700); Warren, Warren S. (7202784679)
Title: Decoherence and programmable quantum computation
Source title: Physical Review A - Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics
Affiliations: Chemistry Department, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ, 08544-1009, United States
Authors with affiliations: Barnes J.P., Chemistry Department, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ, 08544-1009, United States; Warren W.S., Chemistry Department, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ, 08544-1009, United States
Abstract: When coherent states of the electromagnetic field are used to drive the evolution of a quantum computer, a decoherence results due to the back reaction from the qubits onto the fields. We show how to calculate this effect. No assumptions about the environment are necessary, so this represents a useful model to test the fidelity of quantum error correcting codes. We examine two cases of interest. First, the decoherence from the Walsh-Hadamard transformations in Grover’s search algorithm is found [Phys. Rev. Lett. 79, 325 (1997)]. Interference effects, and decoherence-dependent phases, are present that could be useful in reducing the decoherence. Second, Shor’s fault-tolerant controlled-NOT gate is examined, utilizing frequency-selective pulses [Proceedings, 35th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (IEEE Press, New York, 1994), pp. 56–65]. This implementation is found not to be optimal in regards to fault-tolerant quantum computation. © 1999 The American Physical Society.

Authors: van Enk S.J.; Kimble H.J.; Cirac J.I.; Zoller P.
Title: Quantum communication with dark photons
Source title: Physical Review A - Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics
Affiliations: Norman Bridge Laboratory of Physics, California Institute of Technology 12-33, Pasadena, CA, 91125, United States; Institut für Theoretische Physik, Universität Innsbruck, Innsbruck, A-6020, Technikerstrasse 25, Austria
Authors with affiliations: van Enk S.J., Norman Bridge Laboratory of Physics, California Institute of Technology 12-33, Pasadena, CA, 91125, United States; Kimble H.J., Norman Bridge Laboratory of Physics, California Institute of Technology 12-33, Pasadena, CA, 91125, United States; Cirac J.I., Institut für Theoretische Physik, Universität Innsbruck, Innsbruck, A-6020, Technikerstrasse 25, Austria; Zoller P., Institut für Theoretische Physik, Universität Innsbruck, Innsbruck, A-6020, Technikerstrasse 25, Austria
Abstract: We show that quantum information may be transferred between atoms in different locations by using “phantom” or “dark” photons: the atoms are coupled through electromagnetic fields, but the corresponding field modes do not have to be fully populated. In the case where atoms are placed inside optical cavities, errors in quantum information processing due to photon absorption inside the cavity are diminished in this way. This effect persists up to intercavity distances of about a meter for the current levels of cavity losses, and may be useful for distributed quantum computing. © 1999 The American Physical Society.

Authors: Ralph T.C.; Lam P.K.; Polkinghorne R.E.S.
Title: Characterizing teleportation in optics
Source title: Journal of Optics B: Quantum and Semiclassical Optics
Abstract: The quantum state of a system may be transmitted from one location to another through direct transmission of only classical information, provided the sender and receiver share a non-locally entangled state of the Einstein, Podolsky, Rosen type. This process is called quantum teleportation. Continuous variable, optical quantum teleportation is characterized in terms of he two-quadrature signal transfer and conditional variances between the input and output states. Criteria are derived to define the classical limits and highlight interesting operating points which are not obvious from a calculation of the fidelity of teleportation alone.
Index Keywords: Light polarization; Optical parametric oscillators; Photons; Quantum computing; Quantum teleportation; Quantum optics

Title: Physical optimization of quantum error correction circuits
Source title: Physical Review B - Condensed Matter and Materials Physics
Affiliations: Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of Basel, Basel, CH-4056, Klingelbergstrasse 82, Switzerland; IBM Research Division, T. J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, New York, 10598, P.O. Box 218, United States
Authors with affiliations: Burkard G., Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of Basel, Basel, CH-4056, Klingelbergstrasse 82, Switzerland, IBM Research Division, T. J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, New York, 10598, P.O. Box 218, United States; Loss D., Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of Basel, Basel, CH-4056, Klingelbergstrasse 82, Switzerland, IBM Research Division, T. J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, New York, 10598, P.O. Box 218, United States
Abstract: Quantum error-correcting codes have been developed to protect a quantum computer from decoherence due to a noisy environment. In this paper, we present two methods for optimizing the physical implementation of such error correction schemes. First, we discuss an optimal quantum circuit implementation of the smallest error-correcting code (the three bit code). Quantum circuits are physically implemented by serial pulses, i.e., by switching on and off external parameters in the Hamiltonian one after another. In contrast to this, we introduce a parallel switching method which allows faster gate operation by switching all external parameters simultaneously, and which has potential applications for arbitrary quantum computer architectures. We apply both serial and parallel switching to electron spins in coupled quantum dots subject to a Heisenberg coupling (Formula presented) We provide a list of steps that can be implemented experimentally and used as a test for the functionality of quantum error correction. © 1999 The American Physical Society.

Authors: Knight P.L.; Murao M.; Plenio M.B.; Vedral V.
Title: Ion trap quantum gates, decoherence and error correction
Source title: Chaos, solitons and fractals
Affiliations: Imperial Coll, London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Knight P.L., Imperial Coll, London, United Kingdom; Murao M., Imperial Coll, London, United Kingdom; Plenio M.B., Imperial Coll, London, United Kingdom; Vedral V., Imperial Coll, London, United Kingdom
Abstract: We analyze the linear ion trap proposal for realizing a quantum computer. We calculate the limits on Shor's factorization algorithm due to spontaneous emission of the ions. A further contribution to decoherence which originates from instrumental fluctuations and imperfections is described. Fault-tolerant error correction is then applied to derive limits on the efficiency of ion trap computing.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Computers; Error correction; Fault tolerant computer systems; Ions; Spontaneous emission; Decoherence; Fault tolerant error correction; Ion trap quantum gates; Quantum theory

Title: Feasibility study of the quantum XOR gate based on coupled asymmetric semiconductor quantum dots
Source title: Superlattices and Microstructures
Affiliations: Device Research Laboratory, Electrical Engineering Department, Univ. of California - Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA 90095-1594, United States
Authors with affiliations: Balandin A., Device Research Laboratory, Electrical Engineering Department, Univ. of California - Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA 90095-1594, United States; Wang K.L., Device Research Laboratory, Electrical Engineering Department, Univ. of California - Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA 90095-1594, United States
Abstract: We propose an implementation of the quantum XOR (controlled-NOT) gate on the basis of coupled asymmetric quantum dots. Results of our numerical simulations show that the coupling constant of the dipole-dipole interaction and the probability of spontaneous emission can be tuned over a wide range by a proper choice of the potential profile, material parameters, and distances between the dots. We argue that the use of the asymmetric potential profile provides better conditions for having the Ising-type interaction between the dots than earlier proposed schemes based on regular symmetric quantum dots biased with an electric field. Our system gives better resolution of different quantum states, avoids any undesirable time evolution of these states, and can be driven with a femtosecond laser. The qubit manipulation and time coherency requirements are also discussed.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Electric fields; Laser applications; Quantum theory; Ultrafast phenomena; Quantum computing; Semiconductor quantum dots

Title: Realizing probabilistic identification and cloning of quantum states via universal quantum logic gates
Source title: Physical Review A - Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics
Affiliations: Laboratory of Quantum Communication and Quantum Computation and Department of Physics, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei, 230026, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhang C.-W., Laboratory of Quantum Communication and Quantum Computation and Department of Physics, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei, 230026, China; Wang Z.-Y., Laboratory of Quantum Communication and Quantum Computation and Department of Physics, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei, 230026, China; Li C.-F., Laboratory of Quantum Communication and Quantum Computation and Department of Physics, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei, 230026, China; Guo G.-C., Laboratory of Quantum Communication and Quantum Computation and Department of Physics, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei, 230026, China
Abstract: Probabilistic quantum cloning and identifying machines can be constructed via unitary-reduction processes [Duan and Guo, Phys. Rev. Lett. 80, 4999 (1998)]. Given the cloning (identifying) probabilities, we derive an explicit representation of the unitary evolution and corresponding Hamiltonian to realize probabilistic cloning (identification). The logic networks are obtained by decomposing the unitary representation into universal quantum logic operations. The robustness of the networks is also discussed. Our method is suitable for a k-partite system, such as quantum computer, and may be generalized to general state-dependent cloning and identification. © 2000 The American Physical Society.

Authors: Boykin P.Oscar; Mor Tal; Pulver Matthew; Roychowdhury Vwani; Vatan Farrokh
Author full names: Boykin, P.Oscar (6603547147); Mor, Tal (7003876209); Pulver, Matthew (6602826313); Roychowdhury, Vwani (7005748408); Vatan, Farrokh (6602909492)
Title: On universal and fault-tolerant quantum computing: a novel basis and a new constructive proof of universality for shor's basis
Source title: Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science - Proceedings
Affiliations: UCLA, Los Angeles, United States
Authors with affiliations: Boykin P.Oscar, UCLA, Los Angeles, United States; Mor Tal, UCLA, Los Angeles, United States; Pulver Matthew, UCLA, Los Angeles, United States; Roychowdhury Vwani, UCLA, Los Angeles, United States; Vatan Farrokh, UCLA, Los Angeles, United States
Abstract: A novel universal and fault-tolerant basis (set of gates) for quantum computation is described. Such a set is necessary to perform quantum computation in a realistic noisy environment. The new basis consists of two single-qubit gates (Hadamard and σz 1/4 ), and one double-qubit gate (Controlled-NOT). Since the set consisting of Controlled-NOT and Hadamard gates is not universal, the new basis achieves universality by including only one additional elementary (in the sense that it does not include angles that are irrational multiples of π) single-qubit gate, and hence, is potentially the simples universal basis that one can construct. We also provide an alternative proof of universality for the only other known class of universal and fault-tolerant basis proposed in [24, 16].
Index Keywords: Codes (symbols); Computational methods; Encoding (symbols); Error correction; Controlled NOT gate; Double qubit gate; Hadamard gate; Quantum computation; Single qubit gate; Fault tolerant computer systems
Conference name: Proceedings of the 1999 IEEE 40th Annual Conference on Foundations of Computer Science

Title: Approaching five-bit NMR quantum computing
Source title: Physical Review A - Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics
Affiliations: Institut für Organische Chemie, Johann-Wolfgang-Goethe-Universität, Frankfurt, D-60439, Marie-Curie-Straße 11, Germany; Biological Chemistry and Molecular Pharmacology, Harvard Medical School, Boston, MA, 02115, 240 Longwood Avenue, United States; Gordon McKay Laboratory, Division of Engineering and Applied Sciences, Harvard University, Cambridge, MA, 02138, United States; Bruker Analytik GmbH, Silberstreifen, Rheinstetten, D-76287, Germany; Institut für Organische Chemie und Biochemie, Technische Universität München, Garching, D-85748, Lichtenbergstraße 4, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Marx R., Institut für Organische Chemie, Johann-Wolfgang-Goethe-Universität, Frankfurt, D-60439, Marie-Curie-Straße 11, Germany; Fahmy A.F., Biological Chemistry and Molecular Pharmacology, Harvard Medical School, Boston, MA, 02115, 240 Longwood Avenue, United States; Myers J.M., Gordon McKay Laboratory, Division of Engineering and Applied Sciences, Harvard University, Cambridge, MA, 02138, United States; Bermel W., Bruker Analytik GmbH, Silberstreifen, Rheinstetten, D-76287, Germany; Glaser S.J., Institut für Organische Chemie und Biochemie, Technische Universität München, Garching, D-85748, Lichtenbergstraße 4, Germany
Abstract: Nuclear-magnetic-resonance (NMR) quantum computation is a fruitful arena in which to develop and demonstrate an enhanced capability for quantum control over molecular systems, regardless of the prospects, which may be limited, for building a quantum computer superior to a conventional computer for any computing task. We demonstrate a five-bit NMR quantum computer that distinguishes among various functions on four bits, making use of quantum parallelism, an example of the Deutsch-Jozsa problem. Its construction draws on the recognition of the sufficiency of linear coupling along a chain of nuclear spins, the synthesis of a suitably coupled molecule containing four distinct nuclear species, and the use of a multichannel spectrometer. Radio-frequency pulse sequences are described to execute controlled-NOT gates on two adjoining spins while leaving the other three spins essentially unaffected. © 2000 The American Physical Society.

Title: Grover’s quantum searching algorithm is optimal
Source title: Physical Review A - Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics
Affiliations: Theoretical Astrophysics, Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM, 87545, MS B288, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zalka C., Theoretical Astrophysics, Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM, 87545, MS B288, United States
Abstract: I show that for any number of oracle lookups up to about [Formula Presented] Grover’s quantum searching algorithm gives the maximal possible probability of finding the desired element. I explain why this is also true for quantum algorithms which use measurements during the computation. I also show that unfortunately quantum searching cannot be parallelized better than by assigning different parts of the search space to independent quantum computers. © 1999 The American Physical Society.

Title: Optical control and entanglement of atomic Schrödinger fields
Source title: Physical Review A - Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics
Affiliations: Optical Sciences Center, Department of Physics, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States
Authors with affiliations: Moore M.G., Optical Sciences Center, Department of Physics, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Meystre P., Optical Sciences Center, Department of Physics, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States
Abstract: We develop a fully quantized model of a Bose-Einstein condensate driven by a far off-resonant pump laser and interacting with a single mode of an optical ring cavity. This geometry leads to the generation of two condensate side modes that grow exponentially and are strongly entangled with the cavity mode. By changing the initial state of the optical field one can vary the quantum-statistical properties of the atomic side modes between thermal and coherent limits, as well as vary the degree of quantum entanglement. © 1999 The American Physical Society.

Title: Pulse sequences for NMR quantum computers: How to manipulate nuclear spins while freezing the motion of coupled neighbours
Source title: Chemical Physics Letters
Affiliations: Isaac Newton Inst. for Math. Sci., 20 Clarkson Road, Cambridge, CB3 0EH, United Kingdom; Dept. Appl. Math. and Theor. Phys., Silver Street, Cambridge, CB3 9EW, United Kingdom; Department of Chemistry, Lensfield Road, Cambridge, CB2 1EW, United Kingdom

Phys., Silver Street, Cambridge, CB3 9EW, United Kingdom; Hervé B., Department of Chemistry, Lensfield Road, Cambridge, CB2 1EW, United Kingdom; Carbajo R.J., Department of Chemistry, Lensfield Road, Cambridge, CB2 1EW, United Kingdom; Freeman R., Department of Chemistry, Lensfield Road, Cambridge, CB2 1EW, United Kingdom
Abstract: We show how to divide a coupled multi-spin system into a small subset of 'active' spins that evolve under chemical shift or scalar coupling operators and a larger subset of 'spectator' spins which are returned to their initial states, as if their motion had been temporarily frozen. This allows us to implement basic one- and two-qubit operations from which general operations on N-qubits can be constructed, suitable for quantum computation. The principles are illustrated by experiments on the three coupled protons of 2,3-dibromopropanoic acid, but the method is applicable to any spin-1/2 nuclei and to systems containing arbitrary numbers of coupled spins.

Title: Computation on an error-avoiding quantum code and symmetrization
Source title: Physical Review A - Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics
Affiliations: Istituto Nazionale per la Fisica della Materia (INFM), Italy; Institute for Scientific Interchange (ISI) Foundation, Torino, I-10133, Viale Settimio Severo 65, Italy

Abstract: Let [Formula Presented] be the state space of a quantum computer coupled with the environment by a set of error operators spanning a Lie algebra [Formula Presented] Suppose [Formula Presented] admits an error-avoiding quantum code, i.e., a subspace [Formula Presented] annihilated by [Formula Presented] We show that a universal set of gates over [Formula Presented] is obtained by any generic pair of [Formula Presented]-invariant gates. Such gates—if not available from the outset—can be obtained by resorting to a symmetrization with respect to the group generated by [Formula Presented] Any computation can then be performed completely within the coding decoherence-free subspace. © 1999 The American Physical Society.

Title: Suppressing environmental noise in quantum computation through pulse control
Source title: Physics Letters, Section A: General, Atomic and Solid State Physics

Authors with affiliations: Duan L.-M., Department of Physics, University of Science, Technology of China, Hefei 230026, China; Guo G.-C., Department of Physics, University of Science, Technology of China, Hefei 230026, China
Abstract: A scheme based on pulse control is described for suppressing noise in quantum computation without the cost of stringent quantum computing resources. It is shown that environment-induced noise and decoherence, whether in quantum memory or in gate operations, all can be much reduced by applying a suitable sequence of bit-flipping and phase-flipping pulses. © 1999 Published by Elsevier Science B.V. Authors: Ohno Y.; Young D.K.; Beschoten B.; Matsukura F.; Ohno H.; Awschalom D.D.
Title: Electrical spin injection in a ferromagnetic semiconductor heterostructure
Source title: Nature
Affiliations: Lab. for Electron. Intelligent Syst., Res. Inst. of Elec. Communication, Tohoku University, Sendai 980-8577, Katahira 2-1-1, Aoba-ku, Japan; Ctr. Spintronics Quant. Computation, Quantum Institute, University of California, Santa Barbara, CA 93106, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ohno Y., Lab. for Electron. Intelligent Syst., Res. Inst. of Elec. Communication, Tohoku University, Sendai 980-8577, Katahira 2-1-1, Aoba-ku, Japan; Young D.K., Ctr. Spintronics Quant. Computation, Quantum Institute, University of California, Santa Barbara, CA 93106, United States; Beschoten B., Ctr. Spintronics Quant. Computation, Quantum Institute, University of California, Santa Barbara, CA 93106, United States; Matsukura F., Lab. for Electron. Intelligent Syst., Res. Inst. of Elec. Communication, Tohoku University, Sendai 980-8577, Katahira 2-1-1, Aoba-ku, Japan; Ohno H., Lab. for Electron. Intelligent Syst., Res. Inst. of Elec. Communication, Tohoku University, Sendai 980-8577, Katahira 2-1-1, Aoba-ku, Japan; Awschalom D.D., Ctr. Spintronics Quant. Computation, Quantum Institute, University of California, Santa Barbara, CA 93106, United States
Abstract: Conventional electronics is based on the manipulation of electronic charge. An intriguing alternative is the field of 'spintronics', wherein the classical manipulation of electronic spin in semiconductor devices gives rise to the possibility of reading and writing non-volatile information through magnetism. Moreover, the ability to preserve coherent spin states in conventional semiconductors and quantum dots may eventually enable quantum computing in the solid state. Recent studies have shown that optically excited electron spins can retain their coherence over distances exceeding 100 micrometres (ref. 7). But to inject spin-polarized carriers electrically remains a formidable challenge. Here we report the fabrication of all- semiconductor, light-emitting spintronic devices using III-V heterostructures based on gallium arsenide. Electrical spin injection into a nonmagnetic semiconductor is achieved (in zero magnetic field) using a p-type ferromagnetic semiconductor as the spin polarizer. Spin polarization of the injected holes is determined directly from the polarization of the emitted electroluminescence following the recombination of the holes with the injected (unpolarized) electrons.

Title: Josephson junction persistent current elements for quantum computation
Source title: Microelectronic Engineering
Affiliations: Department of Applied Physics, DIMES Institute, Delft University of Technology, 2600 GA Delft, P.O. Box 5046, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Mooij J.E., Department of Applied Physics, DIMES Institute, Delft University of Technology, 2600 GA Delft, P.O. Box 5046, Netherlands
Abstract: Qubits are the basic elements for quantum computers. By developing state-of-the-art qubits, the performance of quantum computers can be significantly improved. In view of this, a new type of qubit has been designed that consists of a closed loop with three Josephson junctions, without connecting leads. The qubit can be operated by modulation of the tunneling barrier.

Title: Quantum decoder for single photon communication

Title: A note on quantum black-box complexity of almost all Boolean functions

Affiliations: Computer Science Division, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720-1776, United States

Abstract: We show that, for almost all N-variable Boolean functions f, N/4 - O(√N log N) queries are required to compute f in quantum black-box model with bounded error. © 1999 Published by Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved.

Title: Can an ideal quantum `Controlled-NOT' gate maintain coherence?
Source title: IQEC, International Quantum Electronics Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: NEC Research Inst, Inc, Princeton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wang L.J., NEC Research Inst, Inc, Princeton, United States
Abstract: A `Controlled-NOT' gate is an elementary building block for an ideal quantum computer. The key advantage of a quantum computer lies in its capability to operate coherently when the quantum bits are in superposition state of the basis states. The operation of an ideal quantum `Controlled-NOT' logic gate is analyzed.

Title: Quantum information

Abstract: A new research direction known as quantum information is a multidisciplinary subject which involves quantum mechanics, optics, information theory, programming, discrete mathematics, laser physics and spectroscopy, and depends heavily on contributions from such areas as quantum computing, quantum teleportation and quantum cryptography, decoherence studies, and single-molecule and impurity spectroscopy. Authors: Sanders G.D.; Kim K.W.; Holton W.C.
Title: Optically driven quantum dot quantum computer
Source title: Annual Device Research Conference Digest
Affiliations: North Carolina State Univ, Raleigh, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sanders G.D., North Carolina State Univ, Raleigh, United States; Kim K.W., North Carolina State Univ, Raleigh, United States; Holton W.C., North Carolina State Univ, Raleigh, United States
Abstract: A design for a quantum computer that builds on n-type SET structures is presented. The design consists of an array of free standing pillars with source drain electrodes at the top and the bottom of the pillar and a stacked series of asymmetric GaAs/AlGaAs quantum wells arrayed along the axis. By applying a negative bias to the cylindrical gate electrode, carriers near the surface are depleted. The parabolic electrostatic potential provides confinement in the radial direction while band gap discontinuities in the quantum wells provide confinement along the pillar axis.

Title: Lateral drag of spin coherence in gallium arsenide
Source title: Nature
Affiliations: Department of Physics, University of California, Santa Barbara, CA 93106, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kikkawa J.M., Department of Physics, University of California, Santa Barbara, CA 93106, United States; Awschalom D.D., Department of Physics, University of California, Santa Barbara, CA 93106, United States
Abstract: The importance of spin-transport phenomena in condensed-matter physics has increased over the past decade with the advent of metallic giant- magnetoresistive systems and spin-valve transistors. An extension of such phenomena to semiconductors should create possibilities for seamless integration of 'spin electronics' with existing solid-state devices, and may someday enable quantum computing schemes using electronic spins as non-local mediators of coherent nuclear spin interactions. But to realize such goals, spin transport must be effected without destroying the relevant spin information. Here we report time, resolved optical studies of non-local Faraday rotation in n-type bulk gallium arsenide, which show macroscopic lateral transport of coherently processing electronic spins over distances exceeding 100 micrometres. The ability to drag these spin packets by their negative charge, without a substantial increase in spin decoherence, is a consequence of the rather weak entanglement of spin coherence with orbital motion in this system.; The importance of spin-transport phenomena in condensed-matter physics has increased over the past decade with the advent of metallic giant-magnetoresistive systems and spin-valve transistors. An extension of such phenomena to semiconductors should create possibilities for seamless integration of 'spin electronics' with existing solid-state devices, and may someday enable quantum computing schemes using electronic spins as non-local mediators of coherent nuclear spin interactions. But to realize such goals, spin transport must be effected without destroying the relevant spin information. Here we report time-resolved resolved optical studies of non-local Faraday rotation in n-type bulk gallium arsenide, which show macroscopic lateral transport of coherently precessing electronic spins over distances exceeding 100 micrometres. The ability to drag these spin packets by their negative charge, without a substantial increase in spin decoherence, is a consequence of the rather weak entanglement of spin coherence with orbital motion in this system.

Abstract: This paper elaborates upon the theory of a semiconductor NMR quantum computer. Authors: Briegel Hans J.; Cirac I.J.; Gardiner C.; Jaksch D.; Zoller P.
Title: Quantum computing in optical lattices
Source title: IQEC, International Quantum Electronics Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Ludwig-Maximilians-Universitaet, Muenchen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Briegel Hans J., Ludwig-Maximilians-Universitaet, Muenchen, Germany; Cirac I.J., Ludwig-Maximilians-Universitaet, Muenchen, Germany; Gardiner C., Ludwig-Maximilians-Universitaet, Muenchen, Germany; Jaksch D., Ludwig-Maximilians-Universitaet, Muenchen, Germany; Zoller P., Ludwig-Maximilians-Universitaet, Muenchen, Germany
Abstract: Controlled cold collisions of atoms in optical lattices allow implementation of highly parallel entanglement operation and quantum gates. Applications include quantum computing with efficient quantum error correction. The use of cold controlled collisions of atoms, trapped in the ground state of the lattice wells, a mechanism to introduce dynamic phase shifts depending on the state of the atoms is proposed. In lattices with ordered filling structures, highly parallel entanglement operations could be implemented, corresponding to a novel class of quantum gates. These multi-qubit quantum gates can be employed for efficient quantum error correction. How the parallelism in an optical lattice could be used for quantum computation in general is discussed.
Index Keywords: Computational methods; Crystal lattices; Phase shift; Optical lattices; Quantum computing; Quantum error correction; Quantum gates; Quantum optics

Title: Coupled quantum dots as quantum gates
Source title: Physical Review B - Condensed Matter and Materials Physics
Affiliations: Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of Basel, CH-4056, Basel, Klingelbergstrasse, 82, Switzerland; IBM Research Division, Thomas J. Watson Research Center, NY, 10598, P.O. Box 218, Yorktown Heights, United States
Authors with affiliations: Burkard G., Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of Basel, CH-4056, Basel, Klingelbergstrasse, 82, Switzerland, IBM Research Division, Thomas J. Watson Research Center, NY, 10598, P.O. Box 218, Yorktown Heights, United States; Loss D., Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of Basel, CH-4056, Basel, Klingelbergstrasse, 82, Switzerland
Abstract: We consider a quantum-gate mechanism based on electron spins in coupled semiconductor quantum dots. Such gates provide a general source of spin entanglement and can be used for quantum computers. We determine the exchange coupling (Formula presented) in the effective Heisenberg model as a function of magnetic (Formula presented) and electric fields, and of the interdot distance (Formula presented) within the Heitler-London approximation of molecular physics. This result is refined by using (Formula presented) hybridization, and by the Hund-Mulliken molecular-orbit approach, which leads to an extended Hubbard description for the two-dot system that shows a remarkable dependence on (Formula presented) and (Formula presented) due to the long-range Coulomb interaction. We find that the exchange (Formula presented) changes sign at a finite field (leading to a pronounced jump in the magnetization) and then decays exponentially. The magnetization and the spin susceptibilities of the coupled dots are calculated. We show that the dephasing due to nuclear spins in GaAs can be strongly suppressed by dynamical nuclear-spin polarization and/or by magnetic fields. © 1999 The American Physical Society.

Title: Quantum computing and single-qubit measurements using the spin-filter effect (invited)
Source title: Journal of Applied Physics
Affiliations: IBM Research Division, T. J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, P.O. Box 218, United States
Authors with affiliations: DiVincenzo D.P., IBM Research Division, T. J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, P.O. Box 218, United States
Abstract: Many things will have to go right for quantum computation to become a reality in the lab. For any of the presently proposed approaches involving spin states in solids, an essential requirement is that these spins should be measured at the single-Bohr-magneton level. Fortunately, quantum computing provides a suggestion for a new approach to this seemingly almost impossible task: convert the magnetization into a charge, and measure the charge. I show how this might be done by exploiting the spin-filter effect provided by ferromagnetic tunnel barriers, used in conjunction with one-electron quantum dots. © 1999 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Sanders G.D.; Kim K.W.; Holton W.C.
Title: Quantum computing with complex instruction sets
Source title: Physical Review A - Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics
Affiliations: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, North Carolina State University, Raleigh, NC, 27695-7911, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sanders G.D., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, North Carolina State University, Raleigh, NC, 27695-7911, United States; Kim K.W., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, North Carolina State University, Raleigh, NC, 27695-7911, United States; Holton W.C., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, North Carolina State University, Raleigh, NC, 27695-7911, United States
Abstract: In most current quantum computers simple electromagnetic pulses implement computations using a minimal set of universal gates. We propose an approach in which quantum control techniques combined with flexible electromagnetic pulse shaping are used to replace several universal gates with a single instruction. We show that this complex instruction set approach can significantly reduce the time required to perform quantum computations. © 1999 The American Physical Society.

Authors: Weinacht T.C.; Ahn J.; Bucksbaum P.H.
Title: Controlling the shape of a quantum wavefunction
Source title: Nature
Affiliations: Department of Physics, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109-1120, United States
Authors with affiliations: Weinacht T.C., Department of Physics, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109-1120, United States; Ahn J., Department of Physics, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109-1120, United States; Bucksbaum P.H., Department of Physics, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109-1120, United States
Abstract: The ability to control the shape and motion of quantum states may lead to methods for bond-selective chemistry and novel quantum technologies, such as quantum computing. The classical coherence of laser light has been used to guide quantum systems into desired target states through interfering pathways. These experiments used the control of target properties - such as fluorescence from a dye solution, the current in a semi-conductor or the dissociation fraction of an excited molecule - to infer control over the quantum state. Here we report a direct approach to coherent quantum control that allows us to actively manipulate the shape of an atomic electron's radial wavefunction. We use a computer-controlled laser to excite a coherent state in atomic caesium. The shape of the wavefunction is then measured and the information fed back into the laser control system, which reprograms the optical field. The process is iterated until the measured shape of the wavefunction matches that of a target wavepacket, established at the start of the experiment. We find that, using a variation of quantum holography to reconstruct the measured wavefunction, the quantum state can be reshaped to match the target within two iterations of the feedback loop.

Title: Holonomic quantum computation
Source title: Physics Letters, Section A: General, Atomic and Solid State Physics
Affiliations: Istituto Nazionale Fisica della Materia (INFM), I-16152 Genova, Italy; Institute for Scientific Interchange Foundation, I-10133 Torino, Viale Settimio Severo 65, Italy; Dipartimento di Fisica, Politecnico di Torino, I-10129 Torino, Corso Duca degli Abruzzi 24, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Zanardi P., Istituto Nazionale Fisica della Materia (INFM), I-16152 Genova, Italy, Institute for Scientific Interchange Foundation, I-10133 Torino, Viale Settimio Severo 65, Italy; Rasetti M., Istituto Nazionale Fisica della Materia (INFM), I-16152 Genova, Italy, Dipartimento di Fisica, Politecnico di Torino, I-10129 Torino, Corso Duca degli Abruzzi 24, Italy
Abstract: We show that the notion of generalized Berry phase i.e., non-abelian holonomy, can be used for enabling quantum computation. The computational space is realized by a n-fold degenerate eigenspace of a family of Hamiltonians parametrized by a manifold M. The point of M represents classical configuration of control fields and, for multi-partite systems, couplings between subsystem. Adiabatic loops in the control M induce non trivial unitary transformations on the computational space. For a generic system it is shown that this mechanism allows for universal quantum computation by composing a generic pair of loops in M. (C) 1999 Elsevier Science B.V.

Title: Quantum computers and quantum coherence
Source title: Journal of Magnetism and Magnetic Materials
Affiliations: IBM Research Division, Thomas J. Watson Research Center, P.O. Box 218, Yorktown Heights, 10598, NY, United States; Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of Basel, Klingelbergstrasse 82, Basel, 4056, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: DiVincenzo D.P., IBM Research Division, Thomas J. Watson Research Center, P.O. Box 218, Yorktown Heights, 10598, NY, United States; Loss D., Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of Basel, Klingelbergstrasse 82, Basel, 4056, Switzerland
Abstract: If the states of spins in solids can be created, manipulated, and measured at the single-quantum level, an entirely new form of information processing, quantum computing, will be possible. We first give an overview of quantum information processing, showing that the famous Shor speedup of integer factoring is just one of a host of important applications for qubits, including cryptography, counterfeit protection, channel capacity enhancement, distributed computing, and others. We review our proposed spin-quantum dot architecture for a quantum computer, and we indicate a variety of first generation materials, optical, and electrical measurements which should be considered. We analyze the efficiency of a two-dot device as a transmitter of quantum information via the propagation of qubit carriers (i.e. electrons) in a Fermi sea. © 1999 Elsevier Science B.V.

Title: Studies of encoding qubits in the quantum logic gates
Source title: Guangdianzi Jiguang/Journal of Optoelectronics Laser
Affiliations: Hengyang Teachers Coll, Hengyang, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhang Dengyu, Hengyang Teachers Coll, Hengyang, China
Abstract: A scheme of error prevention and error correction using quantum-byte controlling quantum-byte in quantum logic operation was proposed. It is suitable for quantum logic gate and quantum computer memory. The qubits service efficiency of this encoding method is 50%, and the process of error prevention and error correction is simple and clear. The dual-rail representation of single logical state provides a foundation for the experiment, so the scheme can be realized easily.
Index Keywords: Error correction; Logic gates; Quantum byte; Quantum encoding; Quantum logic gates; Quantum optics

Authors: Berman G.P.; Campbell D.K.; Doolen G.D.; Nagaev K.E.
Author full names: Berman, Gennady P. (7006050637); Campbell, David K. (7404496607); Doolen, Gary D. (7004866449); Nagaev, Kirill E. (6603851019)
Title: Electron-nuclear spin dynamics in a mesoscopic solid-state quantum computer
Source title: Microelectronic Engineering
Affiliations: Theoretical Division, T-13, MS B213, Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States; Department of Physics, Univ. Illinois Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, IL 61801-3080, 1110 West Green St., United States; Inst. of Radioeng. and Electron., Russian Academy of Sciences, 103907 Moscow, Mokhovaya St. 11, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Berman G.P., Theoretical Division, T-13, MS B213, Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States; Campbell D.K., Department of Physics, Univ. Illinois Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, IL 61801-3080, 1110 West Green St., United States; Doolen G.D., Theoretical Division, T-13, MS B213, Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States; Nagaev K.E., Inst. of Radioeng. and Electron., Russian Academy of Sciences, 103907 Moscow, Mokhovaya St. 11, Russian Federation
Abstract: In order to numerically simulate the process of nuclear spin measurement in Kane's quantum computer, the quantum dynamics of two coupled nuclear spins on 31P donors implanted on Si were modeled. The minimum time of measurement necessary for the reliable transfer of quantum information from the nuclear spin subsystem to the electronic subsystem was estimated. Further, the probability of error for typical values of external noise was calculated.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Electrons; Error analysis; Ion implantation; Mathematical models; Phosphorus; Quantum theory; Silicon; Solid state devices; Electron nuclear spin dynamics; Error probability; Nuclear spins; Quantum computer; Quantum electronics

Title: Multiqubit spin
Source title: JETP Letters
Affiliations: Kazan Physicotechnical Institute, Kazan Natl. Sci. Ctr. Russ. Acad. S., 420029 Kazan, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Kessel' A.R., Kazan Physicotechnical Institute, Kazan Natl. Sci. Ctr. Russ. Acad. S., 420029 Kazan, Russian Federation; Ermakov V.L., Kazan Physicotechnical Institute, Kazan Natl. Sci. Ctr. Russ. Acad. S., 420029 Kazan, Russian Federation
Abstract: It is proposed that the state space of quantum objects with a complicated discrete spectrum be used as a basis for multiqubit recording and processing of information in a quantum computer. As an example, nuclear spin 3/2 is considered. The possibilities of writing and reading two quantum bits of information, preparation of the initial state, and the implementation of the operations "rotation" and "controlled negation," which are sufficient for constructing complex algorithms, are demonstrated. © 1999 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Linden N.; Kupče E.; Freeman R.
Author full names: Linden, Noah (7003906790); Kupče, Eriks (56244500200); Freeman, Ray (35575889600)
Title: NMR quantum logic gates for homonuclear spin systems
Source title: Chemical Physics Letters
Affiliations: Isaac Newton Inst. for Math. Sci., 20 Clarkson Road, Cambridge CB3 0EH, United Kingdom; Dept. Appl. Math. and Theor. Phys., Silver Street, Cambridge CB3 9EW, United Kingdom; Varian Ltd., 28 Manor Road, Walton-on-Thames, Surrey KT12 2QF, United Kingdom; Department of Chemistry, Lensfield Road, Cambridge CB2 1EW, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Linden N., Isaac Newton Inst. for Math. Sci., 20 Clarkson Road, Cambridge CB3 0EH, United Kingdom, Dept. Appl. Math. and Theor. Phys., Silver Street, Cambridge CB3 9EW, United Kingdom; Kupče E., Varian Ltd., 28 Manor Road, Walton-on-Thames, Surrey KT12 2QF, United Kingdom; Freeman R., Department of Chemistry, Lensfield Road, Cambridge CB2 1EW, United Kingdom
Abstract: If NMR systems are to be used as practical quantum computers, the number of coupled spins will need to be so large that it is not feasible to rely on purely heteronuclear spin systems. The implementation of a quantum logic gate imposes certain constraints on the motion of those spins not directly involved in that gate, the so-called 'spectator' spins; they must be returned to their initial states at the end of the sequence. As a result, a homonuclear spin system where there is appreciable coupling between every pair of spins would seem to require a refocusing scheme that doubles in complexity and duration for every additional spectator spin. Fortunately, for the more realistic practical case where long-range spin-spin couplings can be neglected, simpler refocusing schemes can be devised where the overall duration of the sequence remains constant and the number of soft pulses increases only linearly with the number of spectator spins. These ideas are tested experimentally on a six qubit system: the six coupled protons of inosine.

Title: Exact quantum theory of a time-dependent system with quadratic hamiltonian
Source title: Physics Letters, Section A: General, Atomic and Solid State Physics
Affiliations: Department of Physics and Technology, Kharkov State University, Kharkov, 310077, Svobody sq.4, Ukraine
Authors with affiliations: Zhukov A.V., Department of Physics and Technology, Kharkov State University, Kharkov, 310077, Svobody sq.4, Ukraine
Abstract: In the paper we present the following results: (i) exact wavefunctions are found for a system described by a quadratic Hamiltonian of the most general form; (ii) an exact quantum propagator is constructed for the above-mentioned system; (iii) the method used in the paper turns out to be essentially simpler for treating time-dependent systems than the traditionally exploited generalized Lewis-Riesenfeld technique. © 1999 Published by Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved.

Title: Magnetic atom optics: Mirrors, guides, traps, and chips for atoms
Source title: Journal of Physics D: Applied Physics
Affiliations: Sussex Ctr. Optical and Atom. Phys., University of Sussex, Brighton BN1 9QH, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Hinds E.A., Sussex Ctr. Optical and Atom. Phys., University of Sussex, Brighton BN1 9QH, United Kingdom; Hughes I.G., Sussex Ctr. Optical and Atom. Phys., University of Sussex, Brighton BN1 9QH, United Kingdom
Abstract: For the last decade it has been possible to cool atoms to microkelvin temperatures (approximately 1 cm s-1) using a variety of optical techniques. Light beams provide the very strong frictional forces required to slow atoms from room temperature (approximately 500 m s-1). However, once the atoms are cold, the relatively weak conservative forces of static electric and magnetic fields play an important role. In our group we have been studying the interaction of cold rubidium atoms with periodically magnetized data storage media. Here we review the underlying principles of the forces acting on atoms above a suitably magnetized substrate or near current-carrying wires. We also summarize the status of experiments. These structures can be used as smooth or corrugated reflectors for controlling the trajectories of cold atoms. Alternatively, they may be used to confine atoms to a plane, a line, or a dot and in some cases to reach the quantum limit of confinement. Atoms levitated above a magnetized surface can be guided electrostatically by wires deposited on the surface. The flow and interaction of atoms in such a structure may form the basis of a new technology, `integrated atom optics' which might ultimately be capable of realizing a quantum computer.
Index Keywords: Atoms; Electrostatics; Magnetic levitation; Magnetic storage; Rubidium; Integrated atom optics; Magnetic atom optics; Quantum computer; Particle optics
